unit_learning_outcomes.description: Interpret data presented in research publications and evaluate the interpretations of others.
Discuss the range of clinical applications of what we understand about the brain-behaviour relationship.
Demonstrate effective written and oral communication skills through assessments and class-based discussions.
Critically analyse relevant theories, models and empirical research in neuropsychology in clinical practice.

enrolment_rules.description: 20cp at 2000 level including (PSY236 or PSYU2236 or PSYX236 or PSYX2236) or (PSY246 or PSYU2246 or PSYX246 or PSYX2246) or (PSY247 or PSYU2247 or PSYX247 or PSYX2247) or (BIOL257 or BIOL2230) or (HLTH214 or ANAT2004) or (MEDI204 or MEDI2300)

assessments.description: Final examination held within the Universityâ€™s formal exam period, in accordance with relevant requirements.
Students submit a 1500 word essay addressing issues relevant to clinical applications of brain behaviour relationships.
Final examination comprising 40 multiple choice questions and 2 extended answer questions in 2 hours
In Class multiple choice test of 40 questions to be completed in 1 hour

data.unit_offering_text:
Session 2, Weekday attendance, North Ryde
Session 2, Special circumstances

school.value: Faculty of Medicine, Health and Human Sciences

data.description: This unit provides an introduction to the academic disciplines of cognitive and clinical neuropsychology, and is taught by academic staff and practicing clinicians. Students will learn how research informs clinical practice, what can be gained from studying individual cases, and how scores on standardised tests can be interpreted. Successful completion of this unit gives students an understanding of normal and abnormal functional neuroanatomy, principles of neuropsychological assessment, and of common and uncommon manifestations of acquired and developmental brain injury. One of the learning objectives of this unit is to provide an insight into the profession of neuropsychology. This unit does not prepare students for clinical practice, but familiarises them with the scientist-practitioner role of a clinical neuropsychologist.
data.title: Neuropsychology in Clinical Practice

description: This unit provides an introduction to the academic disciplines of cognitive and clinical neuropsychology, and is taught by academic staff and practicing clinicians. Successful completion of this unit gives students an understanding of normal and abnormal functional neuroanatomy, principles of neuropsychological assessment, and of common and uncommon manifestations of acquired and developmental brain injury. One of the learning objectives of this unit is to provide an insight into the profession of neuropsychology. This unit does not prepare students for clinical practice, but familiarises them with the scientist-practitioner role of a clinical neuropsychologist.
title: Neuropsychology in Clinical Practice
